pullRequest.body:
We define the notion `IsHomLift` which aims to provide API for working with equalities `p(\phi) = f` for a functor `p` and morphisms `\phi`, `f`. This API is extensively used in an upcoming PR defining the notion of fibered categories. See the repository [Stacks-project](https://github.com/Paul-Lez/Stacks-project) for WIP using this notion.

Co-authored-by: Paul Lezau <paul.lezeau@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Okay, I've made some changes now. ~~One thing to note is that the file is significantly slower than before on my computer, but maybe this doesn't matter so much~~ (this was just due to some lemmas that shouldnt have been tagged with `@[simp]`, this has been fixed now). 

Another thing that would be nice, but I'm not sure how to add, is if `aesop_cat` (or simp) could deduce `domain_eq` and `codomain_eq` given that a suitable instance of `IsHomLift` is available. That would be helpful for automation when defining  `IsHomLift` instances. For example, I feel that the `domain_eq` field of `comp_lift_id_right` should be able to be automated. Do you know if this is possible in any way?

One thought I just had, is that maybe it could be a good idea to add the class `IsObjLift`, which would allow type-class inference to infer `domain_eq` and `codomain_eq`. But maybe this is a bit overkill.

> One thought I just had, is that maybe it could be a good idea to add the class `IsObjLift`, which would allow type-class inference to infer `domain_eq` and `codomain_eq`. But maybe this is a bit overkill.

I have added a suggestion of alternate proof for `comp_lift_id_right`. If we can be avoid introducing `IsObjLift`. It is probably better!

(In proofs involving a map `f` over another map `g`, I think that in many cases, we should be able to do substitutions so that we may assume that `g` is definitionally `p.map f`: first substitute the equality of objects (as I did above), then `simp` the map equality to get rid of the `eqToHom`, and then substitute the equality of maps.)

> > One thought I just had, is that maybe it could be a good idea to add the class `IsObjLift`, which would allow type-class inference to infer `domain_eq` and `codomain_eq`. But maybe this is a bit overkill.
> 
> I have added a suggestion of alternate proof for `comp_lift_id_right`. If we can be avoid introducing `IsObjLift`. It is probably better!
> 
> (In proofs involving a map `f` over another map `g`, I think that in many cases, we should be able to do substitutions so that we may assume that `g` is definitionally `p.map f`: first substitute the equality of objects (as I did above), then `simp` the map equality to get rid of the `eqToHom`, and then substitute the equality of maps.)

Thanks a lot! I will keep this in mind for the other proofs in this PR (I think it might become especially relevant for the other IsFibered PR). I didn't know that rfl could be used as a pattern like that, thats very good to know, so thanks a lot!
I have now fixed your comments, as well as redefined `IsHomLift` using inductive types as in the zulip thread. I also added a macro `subst_hom_lift` to make the substitution a bit more readable.

I'm not convinced about using `IsHomLift` as a class anymore, basically for the following two reasons:
1. `IsHomLift p f œÜ` makes it so that I can leave parameters `p, f, œÜ` implicit, which makes it slightly more convenient to apply lemmas which has it as a parameter. Especially in situations where the expressions for `f` and `œÜ` are somewhat complicated (involving `eqToHoms` ) it would be quite convenient to not have to write them down explicitly.
2. There are often situations where type-class inference can't infer `IsHomLift`, and having it as a class makes it quite inconvenient to try and give this instance explicitly. For example the following lemma is very simple, but can't be inferred by type-class inference:
`protected lemma id {p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ} {R : ùíÆ} {a : ùí≥} (ha : p.obj a = R) : p.IsHomLift (ùüô R) (ùüô a) := `.
So whenever I want to use this instance, I have to either have another line before with a have statement, which feels inconvenient for such a simple lemma, or use `@` notation.

Also, I havn't felt many of the benefits of having it as a class, I think the only noticeable thing to me is that `IsHomLift.comp` can be inferred, which can be quite nice.

It is very possible that I am not fully using the benefits of having a class (and that these issues shouldn't arise if I use it correctly), so please take what I say with a grain of salt :)

>     1. `IsHomLift p f œÜ` makes it so that I can leave parameters `p, f, œÜ` implicit, which makes it slightly more convenient to apply lemmas which has it as a parameter. Especially in situations where the expressions for `f` and `œÜ` are somewhat complicated (involving `eqToHoms` ) it would be quite convenient to not have to write them down explicitly.

The change of design (using an inductive type, the API for substitutions, etc) makes it so that in principle, you should not need to write that many lemmas where `eqToHom` should appear in the assumptions (although, they may occasionally appear in the statements).

>     2. There are often situations where type-class inference can't infer `IsHomLift`, and having it as a class makes it quite inconvenient to try and give this instance explicitly. For example the following lemma is very simple, but can't be inferred by type-class inference:
>        `protected lemma id {p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ} {R : ùíÆ} {a : ùí≥} (ha : p.obj a = R) : p.IsHomLift (ùüô R) (ùüô a) := `.

We should basically almost never need to use this lemma, because we may do `subst ha`, and then the instance can be infered!

Okay, this makes sense. I think the times I have encountered it has all been in short term-mode proofs, when I had to change the proof from 1 to 2 lines because of this. But then like you say this will be the worst case, as in longer proofs I should just do the substitution first. So I am happy with it :)

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9370445506/job/25797420145)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9370445506/job/25797420496)
I've left some superficial comments but this looks good to go to me.

```suggestion
  domain_eq : p.obj a = R
```
The syntax without the braces is prefered. Also, as this field is a "lemma", the initial should not be capitalized. The tactic `by aesop_cat` could be added as default so as to ease automation.

Did you consider making `IsHomLift` a type-class? It seems reasonable to think that it may be convenient. I would suggest the following:

```lean
class Functor.IsHomLift (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) {R S : ùíÆ} {a b : ùí≥} (f : R ‚ü∂ S) (œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b) : Prop where
  domain_eq : p.obj a = R := by aesop_cat
  codomain_eq : p.obj b = S := by aesop_cat
  fac : f = eqToHom domain_eq.symm ‚â´ p.map œÜ ‚â´ eqToHom codomain_eq := by aesop_cat

instance (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) {a b : ùí≥} (f : a ‚ü∂ b) : p.IsHomLift (p.map f) f where
instance (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) (a : ùí≥) : p.IsHomLift (ùüô (p.obj a)) (ùüô a) where
```
Thanks! I will experiment a bit with making it a class

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion [hœÜ : IsHomLift p f œÜ] : p.map œÜ = eqToHom hœÜ.domain_eq ‚â´ f ‚â´ ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion [hœÜ : IsHomLift p f œÜ] : f = p.map œÜ := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion [hœÜ : IsHomLift p f œÜ] [IsIso œÜ] : IsIso f := ```

In order to ease automation, just stating an equality as I suggested is the simpler way. Then, you may introduce lemmas expressing the different variants (`top ‚â´right = left ‚â´bottom`, `top = ...`, `bottom = ...`), including a `commSq` lemma and an alternative constructor for `IsHomLift` which would take a `commSq` as a parameter.
Okay, that's a great point. Will fix that!

The idea of using a typeclass is that the parameter should no longer need a name `hœÜ`. You should state lemmas like `domain_eq_of_isHomLift` which would take `p`, `f`, `œÜ`, and `[IsHomLift p f œÜ]` as parameters and would produce the expected equality. Then, instead of `hœÜ.domain_eq`, you would write `domain_eq_of_isHomLift p f œÜ`.

Should I never do `hœÜ.domain_eq`? I get that it adds automation, so I should definitely add the simp lemma `domain_eq_of_isHomLift`, but I feel that  `hœÜ.domain_eq` is a lot shorter than `domain_eq_of_isHomLift p f œÜ`
You may try to find a shorter name instead of `domain_eq_of_isHomLift`: it could be a very short name inside a suitable namespace that the user may conveniently `open`!

```suggestion
variable {ùíÆ : Type u‚ÇÅ} {ùí≥ : Type u‚ÇÇ} [Category.{v‚ÇÅ} ùí≥] [Category.{v‚ÇÇ} ùíÆ]
```
The docstring should make more explicit in which category `œÜ` is and what are the source/target categories for `p`.

As the first five lemmas have the same parameters, you could define them in a section:

```suggestion

section

variable (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) {R S : ùíÆ} {a b : ùí≥} (f : R ‚ü∂ S) (œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b) [p.IsHomLift f œÜ]

lemma domain_eq  : p.obj a = R :=
  Functor.IsHomLift.domain_eq f œÜ
```
Also, `p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ` could be defined as a variable more globally in this file.

This seems more appropriate to me:
```suggestion
lemma eq_of_isHomLift (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) {a b : ùí≥} (f : p.obj a ‚ü∂ p.obj b) (œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b)
    [p.IsHomLift f œÜ] : f = p.map œÜ := by
  simpa only [eqToHom_refl, comp_id, id_comp] using fac p f œÜ
```

This cannot be a `simp` lemma, because Lean cannot spontaneously find the assumption `p.obj a = R`.
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
/-- If `œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b` lifts `f` and `œà : b ‚ü∂ c` lifts `ùüô T`, then `œÜ  ‚â´ œà` lifts `f` -/
lemma comp_lift_id_right (p : ùí≥ ‚•§ ùíÆ) {R S : ùíÆ} {a b c : ùí≥} (f : R ‚ü∂ S)
    (œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b) [p.IsHomLift f œÜ] (œà : b ‚ü∂ c) (T : ùíÆ) [p.IsHomLift (ùüô T) œà] :
    p.IsHomLift f (œÜ ‚â´ œà) := by
  obtain rfl : S = T := by rw [‚Üê codomain_eq p f œÜ, domain_eq p (ùüô T) œà]
  simpa using inferInstanceAs (p.IsHomLift (f ‚â´ ùüô S) (œÜ ‚â´ œà))
 ```
Same as above.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion eqToHom (codomain_eq p f œÜ).symm := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (eqToHom (codomain_eq p f œÜ)) f where ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (eqToHom (codomain_eq p f œÜ)) f where ```

```suggestion
/-- If `œÜ : a ‚ü∂ b` and `œà : b ‚ü∂ c` lift `ùüô R`, then so does `œÜ ‚â´ œà` -/
```

```suggestion
    [p.IsHomLift f œÜ] : p.IsHomLift (eqToHom h ‚â´ f) œÜ :=
```

```suggestion
    [p.IsHomLift f œÜ] : p.IsHomLift (f ‚â´ eqToHom h) œÜ :=
```

```suggestion
    p.IsHomLift (eqToHom h ‚â´ f) œÜ ‚Üî p.IsHomLift f œÜ where
```

```suggestion
    p.IsHomLift (f ‚â´ eqToHom h) œÜ ‚Üî p.IsHomLift f œÜ where
```

In other places in mathlib, we would use the following naming convention (and similarly below):
```suggestion
lemma isoOfIsoLift_inv_hom_id {R S : ùíÆ} {a b : ùí≥} (f : R ‚ü∂ S) (œÜ : a ‚âÖ b) [p.IsHomLift f œÜ.hom] :
```
I do not have olean files now, but you may try a proof of this lemma `by simpa using (isoOfIsoLift p f œÜ).inv_hom_id`.

I would suggest you define directly both the `hom` and `inv` fields of this `isoOfIsoLift`, so that the proof of `isoOfIsoLift_hom` becomes `rfl`. This may facilitate some future proofs, because `dsimp` would already be able to simplify.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [‚Üê p.map_id]; infer_instance ```

The following syntax would automatically generate the next lemma:
```suggestion
@[simps hom]
def isoOfIsoLift  {R S : ùíÆ} {a b : ùí≥} (f : R ‚ü∂ S) (œÜ : a ‚âÖ b) [p.IsHomLift f œÜ.hom] :
```
Perfect! Thanks :)

```suggestion
lemma codomain_eq : p.obj b = S := by
```

```suggestion
  subst ha hb h
  simp
```
This and the next three lemmas can be instances. Is there a reason you want to keep them as lemmas?
Can they? How will the hypothesis `hR` be inferred?
Aah of course you're right. Thanks!

```suggestion
  subst h; simp_all
```
`aesop?` reveals that it's just doing `simp_all` so you may as well do it directly. Similar comment for the next three lemmas.

```suggestion
  have : p.IsHomLift (asIso f).hom (asIso œÜ).hom := by simp_all
  IsHomLift.inv_lift_inv p (asIso f) (asIso œÜ)
```
My instinct is to avoid all the @ nonsense.

```suggestion
  (IsIso.inv_id (X := S)) ‚ñ∏ (IsHomLift.inv p _ œÜ)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberedCategory/HomLift): definition of IsHomLift

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberCategory/Fibered): define fibered functors

source.title: feat(FiberedCategory/BasedCategory): add bicategory of based categories
[Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberedCategory/Cartesian): define cartesian morphisms
[Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberedCategory/Cartesian): define strongly cartesian morphisms
[Merged by Bors] - feat(FiberedCategory/Fibered): define prefibered categories

nodes.body: I've left some superficial comments but this looks good to go to me.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9370445506/job/25797420145)
